Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Situation2: They manage high-value transactions at the end of a shift, where mistakes could cause significant financial discrepancies.
Story: I was counting the cash drawer at the end of my shift, my mind focused on making sure every bill and coin matched the receipts. The store was quiet, but the pressure was high—any mistake could mean hours of searching for a missing dollar, or worse, suspicion from my manager. Just as I was double-checking the totals, I heard my name. It was Jamie, someone I knew from my apartment building. She smiled and leaned on the counter, asking if I could recommend a good restaurant nearby for her visiting parents. I felt the pull of two worlds: as an acquaintance, I wanted to be friendly and helpful, to offer a thoughtful suggestion and maybe even chat for a minute. But as the cashier, I knew I couldn’t afford to lose focus, not with the register open and the numbers needing my full attention. My hands hovered over the bills, my mind racing between the urge to help Jamie and the responsibility to finish my work without error.
